intro: Zaleya pentandra var. flava, commonly known as the yellow marsh-orchid, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland and marshy habitats in North America. It belongs to the orchid family (Orchidaceae) and is characterized by its showy, yellowish-orange flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender, upright stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are borne in clusters at the top of the stems and are pollinated by insects, particularly bees. This species is often found in areas with saturated soil and is an important component of wetland ecosystems.
